titlestmt.title: Letter to Dawson Turner, 9 June 1818 : electronic edition
titlestmt.principal: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
titlestmt.sponsor: The Library of Congress, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and the University of Rochester

filedesc.extent: 1 XML file approx. 20.5KB; 4 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 500KB to 1.6MBKB
filedesc.publicationstmt: Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; Carolina Digital Library and ArchivesFebruary 2019

objinfo.objsize: full sheet 20.5 x 32.4 cm.Unfolded full sheet and Leaf Size dimensions (height x width) are given according to the vertical orientation of the body of Blake's letter; see the note on Number of Leaves, below. Object 1 has been reoriented vertically in the Object View Page, as would be customary when reading the address.
objinfo.numberleaves: 2The full sheet was folded to form two leaves. The letter appears on the first recto (Object 2), first verso (Object 3), and second recto (Object 4) of the folded sheet. This folded sheet was folded further to form a sealed packet for posting. The address appears on the second verso (Object 1), which would have been the exterior of the folded packet. The letter appears to have been repaired along the corner of the leaf containing Objects 1 and 4, probably where a wafer seal was torn open. Traces of what appear to be a wafer seal, no longer present, are visible along the edges of the folded letter.
objinfo.sealDesc: Traces of what appears to have been a wafer seal are visible; see note on Number of Leaves above.

provenance.name: Rosenbach Museum and Library
provenance.note: Dawson Turner; sold with the Dawson Turner collection at Puttick and Simpson's, London, 6-10 June 1859, as part of lot 676, "AUTOGRAPHS: SECOND SERIES; 6 vols." (£24); offered by J. S. Davey for £6.6.o. (Keynes *Letters*, page 215); acquired by W. A. White who lent it to the Grolier Club in 1905 and the Fogg Art Museum in 1924; on White's death in 1929, sold to A. S. W. Rosenbach; bequeathed to Rosenbach Museum and Library, Philadelphia.

objnote.p: The full sheet was folded to form two leaves. The letter appears on the first recto (Object 2), first verso (Object 3), and second recto (Object 4) of the folded sheet. This folded sheet was folded further to form a sealed packet for posting. The address appears on the second verso (Object 1), which would have been the exterior of the folded packet. The letter appears to have been repaired along the corner of the leaf containing Objects 1 and 4, probably where a wafer seal was torn open. Traces of what appear to be a wafer seal, no longer present, are visible along the edges of the folded letter.

In the bottom left corner, reoriented vertically, "1010/2" is inscribed in pencil in an unknown hand. In the bottom right corner, reoriented vertically, a few illegible characters are inscribed in pencil in an uknown hand.

lg.l: To
Dawson Turner EsqreEsquire
Yarmouth
Norfolk

desc.objtitle: I send you a List of the different Works, Object 2

objnote.p: The full sheet was folded to form two leaves. The letter appears on the first recto (Object 2), first verso (Object 3), and second recto (Object 4) of the folded sheet. This folded sheet was folded further to form a sealed packet for posting. The address appears on the second verso (Object 1), which would have been the exterior of the folded packet. The letter appears to have been repaired along the corner of the leaf containing Objects 1 and 4, probably where a wafer seal was torn open. Traces of what appear to be a wafer seal, no longer present, are visible along the edges of the folded letter.
In the top left corner, "E L 3 / .B636 / MS1" is inscribed in pencil in an unknown hand.

lg.l: Sir
I send you a List of the different Works
you have done me the honourhonor to enquireinquire after_
unprofitable enough to me thothough Expensive to the Buyer
Those I Printed for MrMr HumphryOzias Humphry are a selection
from the different Books of such as could be PrintedBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1648) reads "such" as "Such".
without the Writingwriting thothough to the Loss of some of the best
things For they when Printed perfect accompany Poetical
Personifications & Acts without Which Poems they neverBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1648), Erdman (page 771), and Keynes (*Letters*, page 142) read "Which" as "which".
could have been Executed £ s d
America 18 Prints folio . 5£ 5 . 0Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1648) and Keynes (*Letters*, page 142) do not read the unclear characters, possibly "£", after "5".
Europe 17 do folio 5 . 5 . 0
Visions &c 8 do folio 3 . 3. 0
Thel . 6 do Quarto 2 . 2 . 0
Songs of Innocence 28 do. Octavo 3 . 3 . 0
Songs of Experience 26 do Octavo3 . 3 . 0

objnote.p: The full sheet was folded to form two leaves. The letter appears on the first recto (Object 2), first verso (Object 3), and second recto (Object 4) of the folded sheet. This folded sheet was folded further to form a sealed packet for posting. The address appears on the second verso (Object 1), which would have been the exterior of the folded packet. The letter appears to have been repaired along the corner of the leaf containing Objects 1 and 4, probably where a wafer seal was torn open. Traces of what appear to be a wafer seal, no longer present, are visible along the edges of the folded letter.

lg.l: Urizen 28 Prints Quarto 5 . 5 . 0
Milton 50 do Quarto 10 .10 . 0
12 Large Prints Size of Each
about 2 feet by 1&½ Historical
& Poetical Printed in ColoursColors
Each 5 . 5 . 0Lines 3-6 are enclosed by a single bracket on the right.
These last 12 Prints are unaccompanied by any
writing
The few I have Printed & Sold are sufficient
to have gained me great reputation as an Artist
which was the chief thing Intended But I have
never been able to produce a Sufficientsufficient number
for a general Sale by means of a regular Publisher
It is therefore necessary to me that any Person
wishing to have any or all of them: Should SendErdman (page 771) and Keynes (*Letters*, page 142) read "Should Send" as "should send".
me their Order to Print them on the above terms
& I will take care that they shall be done at

objnote.p: The full sheet was folded to form two leaves. The letter appears on the first recto (Object 2), first verso (Object 3), and second recto (Object 4) of the folded sheet. This folded sheet was folded further to form a sealed packet for posting. The address appears on the second verso (Object 1), which would have been the exterior of the folded packet. The letter appears to have been repaired along the corner of the leaf containing Objects 1 and 4, probably where a wafer seal was torn open. Traces of what appear to be a wafer seal, no longer present, are visible along the edges of the folded letter.

lg.l: least as well as any I have yet Produced
I am Sir with many thanks for your very
Polite approbation of my works
Your most obedient Servant
9 June 1818
William Blake
17 South Molton Street
